"AlphaSense is seeking smart, innovative and ambitious technology and financial services professionals to join its growing global team.    We look for outstanding candidates in cross-functional areas that include: Computational linguistics, search engine technologies, cloud computing, and securities research.    We are always looking for excellent problem solvers with a sharp intellect and demonstrated creativity."    Does that make sense?    If you're interested, I sent this cover letter along with my resume.      "I noticed that my former colleague, Ian Chodos recently joined your firm so I checked out your website.  It‚Äôs sophisticated search for research is a fascinating concept that is sorely needed by investors.  Publishers also must love firms like you who build tools that make their content more discoverable.    At Bloomberg and Dow Jones I gained significant experience with text parsing, search and sales in the context of institutional investors and decided to sent you this note with my resume.    At Bloomberg I was responsible for a text mining process called Message Mining.  Buy-side firms were desperate to free the millions of OTC price quotes they received via email each day from their in-boxes.  We ingested the content, used regular expressions and other pattern matching methods to identify these prices.  Positive matches were then validated against known securities and prices.  Validated data was made available to both the sender and receiver.      While Message Mining searched for specific kinds of data, it got me very interested in the concept of improving search results by using creative indexing techniques.    At Dow Jones I was asked to look into improving the Factiva news aggregation platform as well as tools for editors to generate the most relevant tags for their stories.  It was fascinating.  I also championed the idea for a data visualization-based search results browser.     I‚Äôm a business and sales person but have a strong interest in programming as a hobby.  If you are interested, I have a personal site at http://steveraaen.com."

So, we finally got my horse, Victor, going again after almost two years off because of two pretty serious injuries (slipping on the ice which hurt one of his hind legs and then tearing a suspensory ligament on a front leg). We'd stop him and start  him, back him up, go from walk to trot and back to walk again, altering the pacing so that he would have to use his hind legs to keep himself together. Friends,    Most of you know that I LOVE community organizers, and am especially happy with my team here in the South Bronx, Mothers on the Move / Madres en Movimiento.  Just when NYC's cynicism was about to swallow me whole, idealism and all, I found this fabulous group of folks.  Can you believe we meditate together before staff meetings?   And we throw fabulous parties... but I'm getting ahead of myself.    For sixteen years, Mothers on the Move (MOM) has brought together South Bronx residents who organize for education, housing, youth and environmental justice.  Even if you've never been to the South Bronx, you've heard about it.  This community is famous for its industrial pollution, unemployment, crime and abandonment.  But there's another story too-- one that I have been privileged to find in every community I've ever visited, and I know you know it too-- its the story of the people who don't give up.  MOM has trained hundreds of South Bronx residents-- Moms, kids, and Dads too-- to take leadership in their community and improve their quality of life.  Whether its quality education, air that won't cause asthma, or housing without leaks and rats, this MOM never stops fighting for her kids.    Saturday, September 27th, MOM is hosting a gala to celebrate these heroes for social justice.  I'm hoping you can come, or at least buy a ticket for one of our friends who can't afford it.  In addition to jamming with our live performers during our cocktail hour and the infamous DJ Laylo later in the evening, we will also enjoy exclusive access to the Bronx Museum of the Arts "Street Art Street Life" exhibition exploring the art of collaboration from the 50's to present day, and delight in Ms. Jessie's Famous Soul Food.   All for just $100 ($50 if you're broke ;)    If you have a message for social justice you want to share with the attendees, of if you want to rep your organization, you can also purchase space in our slide show-- you can send words and images, or even a few seconds of video.  (minimum donation $100)    You can reserve your tickets by making a donation on line at www.mothersonthemove.org or letting me know its in the mail (928 Intervale Ave, Bronx NY, 10459.)
